default.title: Help
default.text: Move your mouse over the interface element that you would like more info about.

help.title: Clear All Layers
help.text: Eject ALL the clips. From ALL the layers.

help.title: Master Bypass
help.text: Makes all output go black.

help.title: Composition
help.text: Previews the composition in the preview window, and brings the composition panel to focus.

help.title: Master Opacity
help.text: Fade all output to black.

help.title: Master Speed
help.text: Speed all the clips up or down.

help.title: Global Play Forward
help.text: Set all clips currently playing to play forward.

help.title: Global Play Backward
help.text: Set all clips currently playing to play backward.

help.title: Global Pause
help.text: Pause all clips currently playing.

help.title: Global Play Random
help.text: Set all clips currently playing to jump to random frames.

help.title: Trigger Previous Column
help.text: Step backwards through the columns.

help.title: Trigger Next Column
help.text: Step forwards through the columns.

help.title: Equalizer
help.text: To fill up this empty space we added a FFT visualizer, allowing you to see the audio. But how can you actually 'see' audio? Can you then also 'hear' video? Is our planet just a fly on the back of a giant bear?

help.title: Column Trigger
help.text: Start all clips in this column at once.

help.title: Clear Layer
help.text: Clear the playing clip from this layer.

help.title: Layer Solo
help.text: Show this layer, the whole layer and nothing but this layer.

help.title: Bypass Layer
help.text: Make this layer invisible.

help.title: Select Layer Blend Mode
help.text: Select one of the many, many blend modes.

help.title: Audio Volume
help.text: Adjust the volume of the layer.

help.title: Layer Master
help.text: Adjust the opacity and volume of the layer in one fell swoop.

help.title: Video Opacity
help.text: Adjust the opacity of the layer. Depending on the blend mode this slider will have different visual results.

help.title: Current Clip
help.text: This clip is currently playing in the layer. Click to adjust its properties in the Clip Properties panel.

help.title: Speed
help.text: Set the playback speed of the timeline. 1 is the normal rate, 2 is twice as fast.

help.title: Timeline
help.text: This timeline indicates the playback position of the clip. Grab the playhead to scrub.

help.title: Clip
help.text: Trigger this clip. Go for it! It's the right clip for this moment.

help.title: Clip Handle
help.text: Click the name of the clip to preview it and to drag the clip to a different position in the deck.

help.title: Relocate Clip
help.text: Click to find this file again somewhere in the darkest depths of your computer.

help.title: Select and Preview Layer
help.text: Click to select, configure and preview this layer.

help.title: Assign to Crossfader Bus
help.text: This will assign this group or layer to the corresponding bus of the crossfader.

help.title: Transition Time
help.text: Control the duration of the transition between 0-10 sec.

help.title: Select Transition
help.text: Select a transition from the list, or go for the random option.

help.title: Trigger Previous Clip
help.text: Step backwards through the clips.

help.title: Trigger Next Clip
help.text: Step forwards through the clips.

help.title: Select and Preview Group
help.text: Click to select, configure and preview this group.

help.title: Clear Group
help.text: Clear all the playing clips from this group.

help.title: Group Solo
help.text: Show this group, the whole group and nothing but this group.

help.title: Bypass Group
help.text: Make this entire group invisible.

help.title: Group Speed
help.text: Set the playback speed of all clips in the group.

help.title: Group Play Forward
help.text: Set all clips in this group to play forward.

help.title: Group Play Backward
help.text: Set all clips in this group to play backward.

help.title: Group Pause
help.text: Pause all clips in this group.

help.title: Group Play Random
help.text: Set all clips in this group to jump to random frames.

help.title: Trigger Previous Group Column
help.text: Step backwards through the columns in this group.

help.title: Trigger Next Group Column
help.text: Step forwards through the columns in this group.

help.title: Group Column Trigger
help.text: Start all clips in this group column at once.

help.title: Crossfader
help.text: First assign layers to bus A and B of the crossfader and then move the fader left to right, right to left *wicka* *wicka*

help.title: Fade to Bus
help.text: Click to switch the crossfader to this bus. The behaviour can be changed in the composition panel.

help.title: Decks
help.text: Decks contain all your clips. A composition can contain multiple decks. Decks are like your records, and your composition is your record bag.

help.title: Deck
help.text: Switch to this deck.

help.title: Select Previous Deck
help.text: Step backwards through the decks.

help.title: Select Next Deck
help.text: Step forwards through the decks.

help.title: Beat Indicator
help.text: A visual representation of the beat of the music. 4 beats to a measure and flashes a yellow outline every 4 measures. Now dance!

help.title: Toggle Link
help.text: This will let Resolume join or leave available Ableton Link sessions.

help.title: BPM Clock
help.text: The Beats Per Minute (BPM) clock can be used to run everything in Resolume to the beat of the music.

help.title: BPM Value
help.text: The current Beats per Minute.

help.title: BPM Adjust
help.text: Adjust the BPM with single increments.

help.title: BPM Nudge Up / Down
help.text: Nudge the BPM up or down temporarily. The nudge percentage can be set in the Preferences.

help.title: BPM Divide / Multiply
help.text: Quickly half or double the current BPM.

help.title: BPM Tapper
help.text: Tap along to the music to set the BPM. Click at least 2 times, click 4 times or more for more accurate results.

help.title: Re-Synchronize BPM clock
help.text: Resets the BPM clock to the first bar. Use this to re-align the BPM clock.

help.title: Pause BPM clock
help.text: Pause the BPM clock.

help.title: Metronome
help.text: Tick tock goes the click clock.

help.title: SMPTE
help.text: SMPTE can be used to synchronize video playback to an external clock.

help.title: SMPTE Input
help.text: Resolume Arena has two SMPTE inputs for dual deck wielding DJ action.

help.title: SMPTE In
help.text: Current timecode of the incoming SMPTE signal.

help.title: SMPTE Input Delay Compensation
help.text: Allows for an offset in frames to compensate for any delays in the incoming SMPTE signal.

help.title: FFT Gain
help.text: Adjust the master gain for FFT input. Use this to boost the level of the incoming audio signal.

help.title: Record
help.text: Record the current video output to disk. Click to start recording, click again to stop and the recorded clip is added to the deck, ready to be used again.

help.title: Monitors
help.text: These monitors can be used to keep track of what's going on. The Output Monitor previews the main mix. The Preview Monitor can be used to preview a layer, group or file before its sent to the mix.

help.title: Monitor Setup
help.text: Click to change the arrangement of the monitors.

help.title: Panel Monitor
help.text: A live preview of what's currently selected in this panel.

help.title: Dashboard
help.text: The Dashboard gives you quick access to parameters you change a lot. Grab a parameter by it's name and drop it onto one of the dials to link it. You can drop more parameters on one dial to control multiple parameters at once.

help.title: Common
help.text: Here you can adjust properties that affect both the audio and video playing in this panel.

help.title: Audio
help.text: Control the audio for this panel.

help.title: Video
help.text: Control the video for this panel.

help.title: Crossfader
help.text: Adjust the behaviour of the crossafder.

help.title: Video Effects
help.text: Adjust the video properties of whatever is selected in this panel.

help.title: Audio Effects
help.text: Adjust the audio properties of whatever is selected in this panel.

help.title: VST
help.text: Open the custom UI for this VST plugin.

help.title: Presets
help.text: Manage your presets.

help.title: Bypass Effect
help.text: Disables the effect without removing it.

help.title: Color Picker
help.text: Select colors from the full spectrum, via HSB sliders, via RGB sliders or even from a Palette of your favorite swatches.

help.title: Composition Panel
help.text: All the info on your composition can be found here. Masks, effects, you name it. Everything you do here is applied on the whole composition.

help.title: Composition Name
help.text: The name and resolution of the current comp.

help.title: Composition Menu
help.text: Open the composition menu.

help.title: Active Layer Panel
help.text: All the info on the active layer can be found here. Masks, effects, you name it. Everything you do here is applied on the current layer.

help.title: Layer Name
help.text: The name of this layer. Click to change.

help.title: Layer Menu
help.text: Open the layer menu.

help.title: Auto Pilot
help.text: The Auto Pilot can be used to play back all the clips in a layer. How's about you let Resolume steer for a while, while you go for that well deserved drink?

help.title: Auto Pilot Play Backwards
help.text: Plays the clips in the current layer in reverse sequence.

help.title: Auto Pilot Play Forwards
help.text: Plays the clips in the current layer in sequence.

help.title: Auto Pilot Pause
help.text: Turns off the Auto Pilot. You are back in command now.

help.title: Auto Pilot Play Random
help.text: Plays the clips in the current layer in random order.

help.title: Transition
help.text: Adjust the transition properties. These controls mirror the ones on the layer.

help.title: Active Group Panel
help.text: All the info on the active group can be found here. Masks, effects, you name it. Everything you do here is applied on the current group.

help.title: Group Name
help.text: The name of this group. Click to change.

help.title: Group Menu
help.text: Open the group menu.

help.title: Active Clip Tab
help.text: All the info on the active clip can be found here. Masks, effects, you name it. Everything you do here is affects the currently selected clip.

help.title: Clip Name
help.text: Click here to change the name of the clip.

help.title: Clip Menu
help.text: Open the clip menu.

help.title: Transport Mode
help.text: Select the timing your clip uses for play back. Timeline let you control the speed manually, BPM Sync matches the clip to the master BPM. On Arena you can also choose the SMPTE source your clip should listen to.

help.title: Clip Transport Controls
help.text: Here you can control how your clip should play back. Forward, backward, quicker, slower, you decide.

help.title: Clip Time
help.text: Time in seconds of the current frame. CLick to switch to remaining time.

help.title: Timeline
help.text: This timeline indicates the playback position of the clip. Grab the playhead to scrub. Move the in- and out-point to trim the clip.

help.title: Timeline Speed
help.text: Control how quickly this clip plays back.

help.title: BPM Speed
help.text: Control how quickly this clip plays back, using BPM and Beats to decide the tempo.

help.title: Setup SMPTE Input
help.text: Quickly switch which SMPTE input this clip should listen to. Also you can adjust its offset here.

help.title: Random Playback
help.text: Jumps to random places on the timeline. When the timeline is in BPM Sync mode, it will jump to a random beat and play, jump to a random beat and play, jump to a random beat and play.

help.title: Loop
help.text: Starts the clip at the beginning when it has reached the end. Starts the clip at the beginning when it has reached the end. Starts the clip at the beginning when it has reached the end.

help.title: Bounce
help.text: Plays the timeline forwards, backwards, forwards, backwards, forwards, backwards, forwards, backwards, ...

help.title: Play Once
help.text: Plays the timeline once and then disappears.

help.title: Play Once and Hold
help.text: Plays the timeline once and then keeps the last frame on screen.

help.title: Restart
help.text: Plays the timeline from the beginning when it is triggered.

help.title: Continue
help.text: Continues playback from the position it was left.

help.title: Relative
help.text: Continues playback from the position of the previous clip. Because why not eh?

help.title: BeatLoopr
help.text: Instantly loop the clip to a beat quantized length. This is fun fun fun!

help.title: Cue Points
help.text: Use these six cue points to jump to different positions in the clip. Press one of the small arrow shapped buttons so set a cue point. Use the corresponding button to jump to that cue point.

help.title: Set Cue Point
help.text: Sets a cue point at the moment you press it. Use the bigger button right of it to jump to that position again.

help.title: Jump to Cue Point
help.text: Jumps to the position set by the small set cue point button on the left.

help.title: Clip Audio
help.text: Info on the audio track of the active clip.

help.title: Clip Video
help.text: Info on the video track of the active clip. Here you can find the codec, resolution, framerate and duration of the active clip. Drag a file onto this area to replace the video track, while keeping all the properties and effects in place.

help.title: Remove Audio
help.text: Remove the audio from the clip.

help.title: Remove Video
help.text: Remove the video from the clip.

help.title: Maximize Video
help.text: Scale the video to the size of the composition.

help.title: Toggle Color Channel
help.text: Switch the R, G and B color channels in the video on or off. Right click to see only this channel.

help.title: Alpha Channel
help.text: If the video has an alpha channel you can use this button to switch it on or off.

help.title: Override Layer Blend Mode
help.text: Using this dropdown, you can force a clip to always use a specific blend mode, regardless of what the layer is set to.

help.title: Generator Parameter
help.text: Adjust the look and feel of this generative source.

help.title: Duration
help.text: This is how long this clip will play when the autopilot is active. The time is set in seconds.

help.title: Video Router Input
help.text: Select the input for this Video Router. You can choose a specific layer, group or the result of the layers below the Router. Also you can select the Preview.

help.title: Video Router Input Opacity
help.text: Choose whether or not this Router should take the opacity of its source into account. Basically this is a pre-fader / post-fader toggle.

help.title: Video Router Bypass Solo
help.text: Choose whether or not this Router should take the bypass and solo switches of its source into account.

help.title: Alpha Channel Interpretation
help.text: Choose how Resolume should interpret the alpha channel of this clip. Premultiplied is usually the way to go. If you see weird halos around your content, switch to Straight.

help.title: Select Server
help.text: Available Servers will show up in this list. You can pick one from the list.

help.title: Camera Input Settings
help.text: Here you can adjust settings for this particular live camera input. If the device supports it, the Video Format will automatically update itself to the correct setting.

help.title: Parameter
help.text: Right-click the name of this parameter to reset it. Grab the name of this parameter and drop it onto a dial on the dashboard to control this parameter with a dial. Click the black arrow to select one of the many parameter animation controls.

help.title: Spinner Parameter
help.text: Hit the + and - buttons to change the parameter incrementally. Click and drag to change it witch coarser adjustments. Right click to reset to the default.

help.title: Toggle Parameter
help.text: Have you tried turning it off and on again?

help.title: Choice Parameter
help.text: This will let you set the control to various states.

help.title: Parameter Value
help.text: The actual value of this parameter, expressed in meaningful units where applicable. So rotation will be in degrees, scale in percentage, audio level in dBs etc.

help.title: Timeline Parameter Animation
help.text: Animate the parameter with a timeline, set the speed, loop, direction, etc.

help.title: Link to dashboard dial
help.text: The value of this parameter will be determined by the dial it is linked to. Note that one dial can be used to control multiple parameters! So you can control a parameter of a video effect AND an audio effect at the same time. Whuuuuut?

help.title: BPM Parameter Animation
help.text: Animates the parameter synchronized to the global BPM clock.

help.title: Invert Value
help.text: Maps the value in reverse. Example: A low input value will result in a high parameter value.

help.title: FFT Parameter
help.text: Animate this paramater to the peak value of the selected audio source. Bouncy bouncy to the bass.

help.title: Envelope
help.text: Remap the output of this parameter using your own custom curves. Double click to add and remove keyframes, right click each keyframe to change its interpolation.

help.title: Search
help.text: Start typing to narrow down the list of results to the entered text. Hit CTRL-? to quickly jump to the search box.

help.title: Slice Browser
help.text: All the slices currently active in the Advanced Output show up here. You can drag them onto the Composition, Group, Layer or Clip panels to create effects that use these Slices as input. Drag whole screens for quick results or individual slices for finer selection.

help.title: File Browser
help.text: Drag files from this browser to one of the clips in the deck to load it. Double click a file to preview it in the preview monitor.

help.title: Directory Up
help.text: Go up one directory in the file system.

help.title: Directory Chooser
help.text: Select a different drive or directory here.

help.title: Best Directory Forever!
help.text: Add or remove the current directory to your list of favorite directories. All directories are equal, but some are more equal than others.

help.title: Show Previews
help.text: When activated the browser will show previews for pictures and video files. This can slow things down a bit when showing a file for the first time.

help.title: Compositions / Decks
help.text: This list contains all your saved compositions with their included decks. Double click a composition or a deck to load. You can load a deck from any composition into your current composition.

help.title: Audio and Video Effects
help.text: List of audio and video effects with their presets. Drag the effect or the preset to a clip, layer, group or composition. or double click to preview it on the current selection.

help.title: Sources
help.text: Various types of video and audio sources. All the capture devices available on your computer, NDI and Spout/Syphon servers, generative FFGL plugins, Feedback fun times and the magical Video Router. Drag to a clip to use or double click to preview.

help.title: Help! Help!
help.text: Don't point that cursor at me!

help.title: Close Help
help.text: If you think you know it all you can close me, go ahead. I'll see you in the view menu!

help.title: Current Time
help.text: I'm late! I'm late! For a very important date! No time to say hello, goodbye! I'm late! I'm late! I'm late!

help.title: Current Version
help.text: Are you up to date?

help.title: Keyboard, MIDI, OSC and DMX Shortcuts
help.text: Every colored interface element can have a shortcut assigned to it. Simply click it and press the keyboard key or Midi message you want to use to control it. Press delete or backspace to remove a shortcut.

help.title: Shortcut Presets
help.text: Here you can change which shortcuts are currently active. Shortcut presets are super handy! You can have different presets for different Midi controllers, or for instance use different presets for different VJ styles.

help.title: Shortcut List
help.text: A list of every shortcut currently active in this preset. If a certain shortcut is used twice, it's shown in red. Shortcuts that are currently unavailble are shown in grey. Right click to change the sorting.

help.title: Shortcut Target
help.text: This is where you decide what this shortcut actually controls. "Selected..." means the shortcut works for the currently selected clip, layer, or group. "This..." means you always control this particular clip, layer or group, regardless of where you move it in the composition. "By Position" means the shorcut is assigned by index. So it for instance will always control the first layer, regardless of how you re-arrange the layers.

help.title: Shortcut Mode
help.text: Here you can change the mode for this shortcut. The two most important ones to know about are Toggle and Value. Toggle will let you switch between two values with each press. Value will always set the parameter to a fixed value. For a wholesome explaination of all the other modes, check the manual. Ugh... Reading....

help.title: Piano Mode
help.text: On key down the parameter will jump to the max value. When the key is released the parameter will jump back to the min value.

help.title: Set Range
help.text: Set the minimum and maximum value of the parameter.

help.title: Mouse Left to Right
help.text: Control the parameter by holding a key and moving the mouse left to right.

help.title: Mouse Up and Down
help.text: Control the parameter by holding a key and moving the mouse up and down.

help.title: Invert Mouse Behaviour
help.text: Up means down and down means up. Left means right and right means left. Turn those frowns upside down.

help.title: Set Valuee
help.text: Use this to set the parameter to a specific value.

help.title: MIDI Message
help.text: When using MIDI learn these are automatically selected but they can be changed manually here.

help.title: MIDI Controller Mode
help.text: Endless dials should be set to 'Relative'. Fixed MIDI controllers to 'Absolute'. Buttons that send out CCs are a crime against nature, but you can use them when set to 'Button'.

help.title: Invert Value
help.text: Make the parameter go from high to low instead of low to high.

help.title: Step Size
help.text: Make the parameter value changes really fine or rough.

help.title: Loop Parameter Value
help.text: Loop the parameter value when the maximum or minimum value is reached.

help.title: MIDI Out Velocity
help.text: Here you can define what velocity this MIDI note sends back to the controller. This well let you choose custom colors on controllers that support it.

help.title: MIDI Out Status
help.text: A dropdown that lets you choose what velocity to send out for each state of the button. For most buttons this is simply a choice between colors for On and Off. But for instance clip triggers can have 5 different states! Colors galore!

help.title: MIDI Out Velocity
help.text: The actual velocity you'd like to send out for this state. This will set the color of the pad. Each controller will use its own color scheme, but to help you get started we have preview swatches for the APC40Mk2 and the APC Mini.

help.title: OSC Input
help.text: OSC input address of the currently selected interface element. The first address is the absolute address and is always valid. The second address will control differnt elements depending on what's currently selected. The incoming address cannot be changed.

help.title: OSC Type Tag
help.text: This tells you what type of argument (float, integer or string) to send to this address, and what range to send it in.

help.title: OSC Output
help.text: Check this box to enable OSC output from the currently selected interface element.

help.title: OSC Output Wildcard
help.text: Use this dropdown to quickly enable OSC output for just this particular element, or for all similar elements in one fell swoop. You can also choose to output a custom address.

help.title: OSC Output Address
help.text: Change the OSC address that this interface elements sends to.

help.title: DMX Lumiverse
help.text: Choose which internal Resolume universe this DMX shortcut is part of. You can assign Lumiverses to an actual physical DMX input in the DMX tab of the Preferences.

help.title: DMX Channel
help.text: Manually adjust the Channel you want this shortcut to use.

help.title: Preferences Window
help.text: Select one of the tabs to adjust your preferences.

help.title: Record Directory
help.text: Location where the recorded files are saved.

help.title: Choose Directory
help.text: Click to set a custom location.

help.title: Record Video
help.text: Choose whether or not you want to include the video output when using the record feature.

help.title: Record Audio
help.text: Choose whether or not you want to record the audio output when using the record feature.

help.title: Audio Output Device
help.text: Choose the device on which you want to hear the audio.

help.title: Audio Input Device
help.text: Choose the device that you want to use for all audio input.

help.title: Master Output Channels
help.text: Choose the channels on which you want to hear the master audio output.

help.title: Master Output Delay
help.text: Slightly delay the audio coming out of Resolume to compensate for any delays in the video signal flow.

help.title: Preview Output Channels
help.text: Choose the channels on which you want to hear the preview audio output.

help.title: Refresh Audio Devices
help.text: Click to check for newly attached audio interfaces.

help.title: Sample Rate
help.text: Higher sample rates provide higher quality audio but will require more processing, especially if audio effects are in use. The default will usually be okay.

help.title: Buffer Size
help.text: Higher buffer sizes will introduce more latency into the system but setting the buffer size too low may cause glitches in the audio. When in doubt, 1024 is a good choice.

help.title: External Audio FFT Input
help.text: Choose the inputs you want to use for audio analysis.

help.title: Audio FFT Input Gain
help.text: Boost the volume of the audio signal coming in.

help.title: SMPTE Inputs
help.text: Choose which audio inputs you would like to use for SMPTE control.

help.title: SMPTE Timecode Framerate
help.text: This should match the framerate of the SMPTE signal that you are receiving.

help.title: VST Plugin Directories
help.text: Directories where Resolume will look for VST plugins. Check the manual for the location of the default plugins.

help.title: Choose Directory
help.text: Click to browse for a custom location.

help.title: FFGL Plugin Directories
help.text: Directories where Resolume will look for additional FFGL plugins.

help.title: Add Directory
help.text: Click to add a directory.

help.title: Remove Directory
help.text: Click to remove the selected directory.

help.title: Dark Transparency Grid
help.text: Change the background to show when previewing content with an alpha channel.

help.title: Refresh Devices
help.text: Click to refresh the list of devices.

help.title: MIDI Devices
help.text: List of all the connected MIDI devices and their available inputs and outputs.

help.title: Show Traffic
help.text: Expand the view to show a list of incoming messages.

help.title: MIDI Traffic
help.text: A list of the last 200 received MIDI messages.

help.title: Enable OSC Input
help.text: Toggle this to listen for incoming OSC messages on the selected port.

help.title: OSC Input Port
help.text: This is the port on which Resolume will listen for incoming OSC messages.

help.title: Enable OSC Output
help.text: Toggle this to send OSC messages to the selected destination.

help.title: OSC Output Selection
help.text: Select where to send your OSC messages.

help.title: OSC Output Port
help.text: This is the port to which Resolume will send OSC messages.

help.title: OSC Output IP Address
help.text: This is the IP address of the computer or mobile device to which Resolume will send OSC messages.

help.title: Use Bundles
help.text: Select whether or not Resolume should bundle the OSC messages before sending them. Most OSC applications will work fine without bundles, but some prefer it.

help.title: OSC Traffic
help.text: A list of the last 200 received OSC messages.

help.title: Add Art-Net Input
help.text: Add an input device to receive DMX from.

help.title: Delete Art-Net Input
help.text: Delete this device.

help.title: Art-Net Node Name
help.text: Set the name this Resolume instance will appear as on your Art-Net network.

help.title: Art-Net Input Settings
help.text: Adjust the Channel Offset and Universe for this input.

help.title: Subnet Number
help.text: Subnet ranges from 0-15. Together with the Universe number, this forms the Art-Net universe this input is listening on.

help.title: Universe
help.text: Universe ranges from 0-15. Together with the Subnet number, this forms the Art-Net universe this input is listening on.

help.title: DMX Channel Offset
help.text: With the DMX channel offset number you can shift all the assigned DMX channels up or down.

help.title: Select Network Adapter
help.text: Choose which network interface Resolume should use for Art-Net. This will let you make sure you're using the wired network instead of the wireless card.

help.title: Art-Net Monitor
help.text: Here you can monitor all the Art-Net traffic on your network. Active Subnets and Universes will light up. You can then select a Subnet and Universe and see the received values for all 512 channels.

help.title: Set Defaults
help.text: Here you can change the values Resolume should use as defaults. Clip defaults are applied when adding new clips to your composition. They do not affect clips that are already there.

help.title: Tempo Nudge Value
help.text: This is the percentage that the BPM will shift up or down while holding down the nudge buttons.

help.title: Composition Settings
help.text: Set things like the compositon name, description and size in this window.

help.title: Composition Size in Pixels
help.text: You can type any size you like here or select one of the predefined resolutions from the dropdown menu.

help.title: Add Items
help.text: Add new screens, slices and fixtures to your output setup.

help.title: Preset Menu
help.text: Save, load and manage different output setups.

help.title: Add Screen
help.text: Create a new screen. A screen can be assigned to any physical or virtual output.

help.title: Add Slice
help.text: Add another slice to the current screen.

help.title: Add Polygon
help.text: Add a Polygon Slice to the current screen.

help.title: Add Triangle Polygon
help.text: Quickly add a Polygon Slice that's shaped like a triangle.

help.title: Draw Polygon
help.text: Add a Polygon slice, you can create any shape by drawing points on the composition.

help.title: Add Mask
help.text: Add a new output mask to the current screen.

help.title: Draw Mask
help.text: Create a mask shape that's limited only by your imagination. Add points by drawing on the composition.

help.title: Add Lumiverse
help.text: Create a new Lumiverse. This is like the Big Bang for DMX fixtures.

help.title: Add Fixture
help.text: Add a new fixture to the current Lumiverse.

help.title: Screen
help.text: Select this screen for editing. Right click to quickly assign an output.

help.title: Delete Screen
help.text: Whoah there, Flash. This deletes this screen and everything in it!

help.title: Enable Screen
help.text: Enable or disable all the slices and masks in this screen in one fell swoop.

help.title: Fold Screen
help.text: Fold up all the slices in this screen. This also hides these slices on the Input Selection tab, so it becomes less cluttered.

help.title: Enable Slice
help.text: Turn this slice on or off in the output.

help.title: Slice
help.text: Select this slice for editing. Right click it for more options or double click to rename it.

help.title: Delete Slice
help.text: Remove this slice completely.

help.title: Input Mask
help.text: Select this input mask for editing.

help.title: Enable Input Mask
help.text: Enable or disable the input mask for this slice.

help.title: Delete Slice Input Mask
help.text: Reveal the true nature of this slice.

help.title: Polygon Slice
help.text: Select this polygon for editing.

help.title: Enable Polygon
help.text: Show or hide this polygon in the output.

help.title: Delete Polygon
help.text: Poly-gone!

help.title: Mask
help.text: Select this mask for editing.

help.title: Enable Mask
help.text: Show or hide this mask in the output.

help.title: Delete Mask
help.text: Remove this mask completely.

help.title: Lumiverse
help.text: Select this Lumiverse for editing. Right click to send it to an Art-Net node directly.

help.title: Enable Lumiverse
help.text: Turn off the fixtures in this Lumiverse in one fell swoop.

help.title: Fold Lumiverse
help.text: Fold up this Lumiverse. This also hides the fixtures on the Input Selection tab, so it becomes less cluttered.

help.title: Delete Lumiverse
help.text: Smite this Lumiverse with the force of nine thousand suns.

help.title: Fixture Slice
help.text: Select this fixture for editing.

help.title: Enable Fixture
help.text: Disable the output to this fixture. This will stop Resolume from sending DMX data to this fixture.

help.title: Delete Fixture
help.text: Remove this fixture completely.

help.title: Input Selection
help.text: Here you can define which part of the composition should be used as input for your slices. Right click for preset options. Use the common ALT/SHIFT/CTRL(CMD) modifiers to constrain and copy.

help.title: Output Transformation
help.text: Change the shape or position of your slices in your output. Each slice can be individually moved and reshaped to line up with your output. Right click for preset options. Use the common ALT/SHIFT/CTRL(CMD) modifiers to constrain and copy.

help.title: DMX Output
help.text: Here you can visually re-arrange the start channels of your fixtures or check for any overlap.

help.title: Zoom
help.text: Zoom the current view in or out, or fit the view to the current selection or composition.

help.title: Pan Tool
help.text: Use this to pan around. Hold down the spacebar as a quick way to toggle the pan tool.

help.title: Undo
help.text: Don't just do it. Undo it.

help.title: Redo
help.text: Undo it what you just undid.

help.title: Toggle Snapping
help.text: Disable or enable that hot slice on slice action.

help.title: Show Grid
help.text: Shows the name and bounds of the currently active slice in the output, so you can quickly locate your slice in a complex output setup. It also shows a perspective grid for the slice surface and a big red cross where your cursor is.

help.title: Show LED Grid
help.text: Shows a 8x8 pixel grid and snaps all slices to it. This is helpful when arranging slices for output to a LED processor.

help.title: Composition Resolution
help.text: Width and height of the composition that is currently used as input.

help.title: Edit Points Mode
help.text: In Edit Points Mode you can change the position or curve of every point on the current slice. Hit T to quickly switch between Edit Points and Transform mode.

help.title: Transform Mode
help.text: Change the position, rotation or scale of the entire slice. Hit T to quickly switch between Edit Points and Transform mode.

help.title: Name
help.text: Everything you wanted to know about your current selection, but were afraid to ask.

help.title: Select Device
help.text: Choose which physical or virtual output this screen should be sent to. Physical outputs are the external displays connected to the computer. Virtual outputs can include Syphon/Spout and NDI, or even screens internally routed within the advanced output.

help.title: Screen Width and Height
help.text: Set the width and height of your virtual output.

help.title: Opacity
help.text: Fades the active screen or Lumiverse in and out.

help.title: Color Compensation
help.text: Use this to adjust for mismatched projectors or differences between LED screens.

help.components: '*' 'Output Guide' | '*' '*' 'Output Guide' | '*' '*' '*' 'Output Guide' | '*' 'Input Guide' | '*' '*' 'Input Guide' | '*' '*' '*' 'Input Guide'
help.title: Guide
help.text: Load an image file to act as a visual guide for your pixel map.

help.title: Screen Delay
help.text: Add a delay in milliseconds to this screen, to compensate for any delay appearing in other outputs.

help.title: Target IP
help.text: The IP address of the Art-Net node that this Lumiverse is sending to.

help.title: Subnet and Universe
help.text: The Subnet and Universe of the Art-Net node that this Lumiverse is sending to.

help.title: DMX Framerate
help.text: Choose how often this Lumiverse should spam your network with those nasty DMX packets.

help.title: Input Source
help.text: Drop down that allows you to choose the input for a slice. There are quite a few options here. You can choose the composition or access a layer directly, bypassing the composition. Also the preview window is available as an input. Even more fun can be had by routing Virtual Screens back into a slice.

help.title: Input Opacity
help.text: Toggle that tells the slice to follow the layer's opacity value, or to always show it, regardless of the layer's opacity value. This is useful when you want to warp a layer in the final output, but not have it show up in the composition.

help.title: Input Bypass/Solo
help.text: Toggle that tells the slice to follow the layer's bypass and solo switches, or to ingore them. This is useful when you want to warp a layer in the final output, but not have it show up in the composition.

help.title: Slice Input X and Y Position
help.text: Position of the middle point of the slice, slice mask or fixture, relative to the composition. This defines which area of the composition you will use for its input.

help.title: Slice Input Left and Top Position
help.text: Position of the left and top edges of the slice, slice mask or fixture, relative to the composition.

help.title: Slice Input Width and Height
help.text: Input width and height of the current slice, slice mask or fixture in pixels. This defines the size of the area of the composition you will use for input.

help.title: Slice Input Rotation
help.text: Rotate the input of this slice, slice mask or fixture, for instance so you can work with rotated LED screens.

help.title: Enable Soft Edge
help.text: Check this box to turn soft edging on or off for the current slice. Use this to blend the output where two or more projectors are overlapping. The output will be masked in the area where the slices overlap.

help.title: Soft Edge
help.text: Information on the soft edge settings of the current slice.

help.title: Soft Edge Power
help.text: Use this to control the steepness of the curve of the soft edge in the blending area.

help.title: Soft Edge Luminance
help.text: Use this to control the brightness of the center point of the soft edge curve in the blending area.

help.title: Soft Edge Gamma
help.text: Use this to control the overall brightness of the soft edge in the blending area.

help.title: RGB Gamma Compensation
help.text: Control the color channels in the blending area.

help.title: Slice Input Mask
help.text: Add a mask to the input of this slice, so you can create transparency.

help.title: Add Heart Input Mask
help.text: Because only love can fill the void.

help.title: Add Input Mask
help.text: Quickly add a preset mask shape to this slice.

help.title: Draw Input Mask
help.text: Draw your own input mask shape on this slice.

help.title: Flip
help.text: Flip the output of this slice or fixture horizontally, vertically or both.

help.title: Toggle Key Channel
help.text: Renders alpha channels as black and white for use with broadcast mixers.

help.title: Black Background
help.text: Renders this slice on a solid black background, even when its opacity is fully down. Useful when objects are partially covering each other in a projection mapping setup.

help.title: Select Fixture
help.text: Select the personality to use for this fixture slice.

help.title: Open Fixture Editor
help.text: Edit the current personality or create a new one from scratch.

help.title: Start Channel
help.text: First channel in your Lumiverse that this fixture will send to.

help.title: DMX Parameter
help.text: Controls specific functionality of this fixture.

help.title: Dip Switches
help.text: There are 10 kind of people in this world. Those who understand binary, and those who don't.

help.title: Fixture Output Preview
help.text: Preview of the RGB data that this fixture is sending out.

help.title: Output Width and Height
help.text: Output width and height of the current slice or mask in pixels. This defines the size in the output.

help.title: Output X and Y Position
help.text: Position of the middle point of the slice or mask, relative to the output. This defines where you will see the slice in the output.

help.title: Output Left and Top Position
help.text: Position of the left and top edges of the slice or mask, relative to the output.

help.title: Color Compensation
help.text: Use this to adjust individual slices or fixtures. In a pinch, ramping up the brightness will also help you locate a slice or fixture on the stage.

help.title: Output Rotation
help.text: Rotate the slice or mask around its center in the final output. Don't rotate it too much, or it will vomit pixels.

help.title: Slice Point Mode
help.text: Choose between linear and bezier interpolation modes for slice points.

help.title: Horizontal Slice Warp Points
help.text: Add or remove horizontal warp points to the current slice.

help.title: Vertical Slice Warp Points
help.text: Add or remove vertical warp points to the current slice.

help.title: Current Point
help.text: X and Y position information of the currently selected point.

help.title: Point X Position
help.text: Position of currently selected point along the x-axis in pixels.

help.title: Point Y Position
help.text: Position of currently selected point along the y-axis in pixels.

help.title: Black Level Compensation
help.text: Adjust the black level of this slice. This will let you match the brightness of an edge blended slice, by adjusting the perceived difference between the non-overlapping and the overlapping area.

help.components: 'Red' 'Black Level Compensation' || 'Green' 'Black Level Compensation' || 'Blue' 'Black Level Compensation'
help.title: Channel Compensation
help.text: Increase the amount of red, green or blue in the black of this slice.

help.title: Invert Mask
help.text: This will switch between masking the inside or the outside of the mask shape.

help.title: Cancel
help.text: Cancels all the hard work you did just now. Closes the Advanced Output, and brings things back to how they were before. Only use this when your middle name is Nostalgia.

help.title: Save and Close
help.text: Confirms all the hard work you did just now. Closes the Advanced Output, applies all the changes and saves the current setup. Use this when your middle name is Pixel Perfect.

help.title: Personality Library
help.text: List of all the fixture personalities in your library.

help.title: Create Fixture
help.text: Create a new personality from scratch.

help.title: Delete Fixture
help.text: Delete the selected personality from the list.

help.title: Add Parameter
help.text: Add a new parameter to this personality.

help.title: Delete Parameter
help.text: Delete the selected parameter from the list.

help.title: Close Editor
help.text: Closes the editor and saves all your changes.

help.title: Fixture Parameters
help.text: Parameters that control the features of this personality.

help.title: Pixel Block
help.text: Block of pixels that can be used to send color data to your fixture.

help.title: DMX Parameter
help.text: Controls specific functionality of this personality. You can drag parameters around to change their order.

help.title: Default Value
help.text: Here you can set the default DMX value that this parameter should send out.

help.title: Pixel Width
help.text: Set how many pixels this fixture contains.

help.title: Color Space
help.text: Choose which channels this fixture can receive and the order they are in.

help.title: Gamma
help.text: Adjust the gamma correction for this personality.

help.title: Distribution
help.text: Define how the channels are distributed over your personality. The open arrow signifies the first channel, the direction of the subsequent arrows define how the channels 'snake' through the fixture.

help.title: Pixel Distribution
help.text: Visual representation of how the channels are distributed over your personality.

help.title: Collect Media
help.text: Gather all the footage used in this composition in one neat location.

help.title: Locate All
help.text: Search for all missing files by selecting a folder. This will search through any subfolders as well.

help.title: Close
help.text: We're done here!

help.title: File Info
help.text: List of all the files in this composition. Missing files are marked in red.

help.title: Relocate File
help.text: Relocate or replace this particular file.

help.title: Update Composition
help.text: Gather all the files in one location. When done, the current composition will be updated with the new paths. Handy for consolidating your composition files in one place.

help.title: Copy Composition
help.text: Gather all the files in one location. When done, the current composition is copied there as well. Handy for moving your composition and files to another computer.

help.title: AV Master
help.text: Fade all clips to black and all sound to silence.

help.title: Master Speed
help.text: Speed all the clips up or down.

help.title: Global Play Forward
help.text: Set all clips currently playing to play forward.

help.title: Select Layer Blend Mode
help.text: Select one of the many, many blend modes.

help.title: Audio Volume
help.text: Adjust the volume of the layer.

help.title: Audio Volume
help.text: Adjust the volume of the composition.

help.title: Audio Pan
help.text: Adjust the panning of the layer.

help.title: Audio Pan
help.text: Adjust the panning of the composition.

help.title: Transition Time
help.text: Control the duration of the transition between 0-10 sec.

help.title: Dashboard
help.text: The Dashboard gives you quick access to parameters you change a lot. Grab a parameter by it's name and drop it onto one of the dials to link it. You can drop more parameters on one dial to control multiple parameters at once.

help.title: Auto Pilot
help.text: The Auto Pilot can be used to play back all the clips in a layer. How's about you let Resolume steer for a while, while you go for that well deserved drink?

help.title: Auto Pilot Play Forwards
help.text: Plays the clips in the current layer in sequence.

help.title: Timeline Speed
help.text: Control how quickly this clip plays back.

help.title: Cue Points
help.text: Use these six cue points to jump to different positions in the clip. Press one of the small arrow shapped buttons so set a cue point. Use the corresponding button to jump to that cue point.

help.title: Directory Chooser
help.text: Select a different drive or directory here.

help.title: Play mode
help.text: Select how Resolume plays back your clips. Loop starts the clip at the beginning when it has reached the end. Random will jump to random places on the timeline. When the timeline is in BPM Sync mode, it will jump to a random beat and play. Bounce plays the timeline forwards and backwards. Play once will, well, just do that.

help.title: Trigger mode
help.text: Select how Resolume triggers your clips. Continues playback from the position it was left. Relative continues playback from the position of the previous clip.

help.title: Screen Picker
help.text: Select a color from anywere on your screen. Pick and choose.

help.title: Color Picker
help.text: Select colors from the full spectrum, via HSB sliders, via RGB sliders or even from a Palette of your favorite swatches.

help.title: HSB Color Space
help.text: Select colors from the full spectrum, via HSB sliders, via RGB sliders or even from a Palette of your favorite swatches.

help.title: RGB Color Space
help.text: Select colors from the full spectrum, via HSB sliders, via RGB sliders or even from a Palette of your favorite swatches.

help.title: Color Pallete
help.text: Select colors from a Pallate. Right click the Pallate for additional options. Pro tip: you can animate your Pallet!

help.title: Presets
help.text: Manage your presets.

help.title: Crossfader Curve
help.text: Adjust the Curve of the Crossfader.

help.title: Crossfader Behaviour
help.text: Make that crossfader behave like a proper little crossfader.

help.title: Crossfader Blend Mode
help.text: Set the Blend Mode for the crossfader.

help.title: Auto Size
help.text: This function will automatically resize all clips within this layer to either fit, fill or stretch to the composition dimensions.

help.title: Duration Ajdustments
help.text: subtraction, addition, multiplication and division. Resolume Elementary.

help.title: Autopilot
help.text: Adjust the behaviour of the clip when in Autopilot mode

help.title: Autopilot Action
help.text: Set the behaviour of the clip when in Autopilot mode.

help.title: Loops
help.text: Determine how many times the clip repeats.

help.title: Clip Blend Mode
help.text: Set a custom blend mode for this clip only. This will overwrite the layer blend mode for this clip.

help.title: Clear All of theLayers
help.text: Eject ALL the clips. From ALL the layers.

help.title: Render Queue
help.text: The queue contains all rendered clips. Drag and drop to use the clip in your composition

help.title: Rendered Clip
help.text: Your Clip. Rendered just right.

help.title: View in explorer
help.text: View rendered clip in the explorer

help.title: Remove from queue
help.text: Remove the clip from the queue. This does not remove the file.

help.title: Create Patch
help.text: Create a new source, mixer or effect in Wire.

help.title: Edit Patch
help.text: Edit this patch in Wire.

help.title: Fork Patch
help.text: Create a copy of this patch and edit it in Wire.

help.title: Monitor Options
help.text: Adjust what you want to monitor (composition, preview, group or layer) and change monitor opacity behavior.

help.title: Favorite
help.text: Select to add or remove this source or effect to your Favorites.

help.title: Pan Tool
help.text: Use this to pan around.

help.title: Widget is disabled
help.text: Transform widget is disabled because either Rotation X, Y or Anchor is not at default value, or multiple clips are selected, or the test card is enabled.
